Award.AbstractNarration:
The award provides funding to support participation of primarily junior researchers (postdocs and graduate students) in the meeting consisting of the workshop ``Elliptic Curves, Torsors and L-functions" and the lectures by B.H. Gross on the ranks of elliptic curves in the Distinguished Lecture Series ``Virginia Mathematics Lectures." The workshop and the lectures will take place March 24-29 at the University of Virginia. The lectures by Gross will include a survey of the Birch--Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture as well as very recent results on the average rank for all elliptic curves over the field of rational numbers and the arithmetic of hyperelliptic curves. The lectures in the workshop will complement Gross's lectures by expanding into related areas of arithmetic geometry and the arithmetic theory of algebraic groups. The meeting is sponsored in part by the Institute of Mathematical Sciences at the UVA Mathematics Department.
The website is http://www.people.virginia.edu/~lww8k/workshop/workshop.html.

The rank is the most important but least understood invariant of elliptic curves over Q. The recent work of M. Bhargava, B.H. Gross, B. Poonen and others on `average' ranks marked a breakthrough in the field by introducing the viewpoint of `arithmetic statistics'; that is, studying the distribution of such arithmetic invariants. The general methods of arithmetic statistics are applicable to many adjacent areas of arithmetic geometry. The objective of the planned workshop at UVA is precisely to cater to the intense interest in these methods from those working on related areas, by bringing together experts on this topic with both senior and junior researchers from adjacent areas of arithmetic geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop ``Elliptic Curves, Torsors, and $L$-Functions'' was held March 24--27, 2017 on the grounds of the University of Virginia. It was followed by three lectures on the ranks of elliptic curves and the conjecture of Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer given by Benedict H. Gross in the Distinguished Lecture Series ``Virginia Mathematics Lectures;''? all participants of the workshop were able to stay at UVA for the lectures. The whole event was organized by Andrew Obus, Andrei Rapinchuk and Lloyd West (all from the Department of Mathematics at UVA). The funding was provided by the Institute of Mathematical Sciences (IMS) at UVA and the National Science Foundation (grant DMS-1660462).

The rank is the most important but least understood invariant of elliptic curves over the field ofrational numbers.  Recent breakthroughs in the area (due to M. Bhargava, B.H. Gross,B. Poonen, ...) have been achieved by introducing the viewpoint of``arithmetic statistics,'' i.e., studying the distribution of arithmetic invariants such as the rank. The proofs of these results are highly technical. On the other hand, the general methods of arithmetic statistics are applicable to many adjacent areas of arithmetic geometry. So, the mission of the workshop was to cater to the intense interest in these methods from those workingin related areas, by bringing together experts on this topic with both senior and junior researchers from adjacent areas of arithmetic geometry and the theory of algebraic groups.

The workshop was attended by about 35 mathematicians from the US and other countries (Belarus, Canada, Israel), including 18 junior participants (junior faculty, postdocs, graduate students) from various schools, with active participation of the faculty and graduate students of the Mathematics Department at UVA. It should be emphasized that the NSF support enabled the organizersto invite  12 junior participants. The scientific program of the workshop featured 11 full-length talks (50 min) and10 short communications (20 min). The talks covered a variety of topics in arithmetic geometry and the theory of algebraic groups including Sato-Tate and Selmer groups, homogeneous spaces of algebraic groups, class groups of number fields and torsion groups of elliptic curves, torsors of algebraic groups, the Bruhat-Tits theory of algebraic groups over local fields, and others. Most of the talks contained surveys of the relevant results in the area and focused on general ideas rather than technical details, which made them accessible to a broader audience but at the same time provided information about very recent developments. The program of the workshop and its overall effect were greatly enhancedby Gross's lectures on the arithmetic of elliptic curves (Lecture 1 -- ``The rank of elliptic curves'' (March 27), Lecture 2 -- ``The arithmetic of hyperelliptic curves'' (March 28), Lecture 3 -- ``Heegner points on modular curves'' (March 29)).
